docs.lead_paragraph: Because our Bob Knight problem was framed as either a moral question -- Is it wrong to throw chairs, talk dirty and choke your players? -- or as a pragmatic question -- Is it imprudent for a university president to jeopardize major donations by dumping an iconic coach? -- we will probably have to deal with the blustery bully for a while. Until he slugs someone who really matters, such as a rich Indiana booster, or has three losing seasons in a row, Knight will continue to have an impact on young lives in formation and offer an affirming role model to abusive coaches and corporate managers everywhere. Had our Bob Knight problem been properly framed as a psychological question -- does this man have a personality disorder and is it having an adverse emotional impact on others? -- we might be a lot closer to getting rid of him, or at least getting him into therapy.
docs.abstract: Robert Lipsyte discusses Indiana University Coach Bob Knight framing his abusiveness toward players as a psychological problem that needs to be addressed; other athletes suffering from depression who have been helped by therapy and medication are discussed but Lipsyte concludes Coach Knight would resist this kind of help; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Because our Bob Knight problem was framed as either a moral question -- Is it wrong to throw chairs, talk dirty and choke your players? -- or as a pragmatic question -- Is it imprudent for a university president to jeopardize major donations by...

docs.lead_paragraph: An influential Republican member of the House and a Democratic senator announced today that they would collaborate on a bipartisan effort to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare this year. The effort, by Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, and Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, alters the politics of the issue in this election year, at least marginally increasing the chances that Congress can break the deadlock on Medicare coverage of prescription drugs.

headline.main: Bipartisan Effort on Drug Coverage Is Begun

docs.abstract: Repr Bill Thomas, influential Republican, and Sen Ron Wyden, Democrat, announce they will collaborate on bipartisan effort to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare this year; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an important advance, researchers in Canada are reporting that transplants of insulin-producing cells have freed eight patients with a severe form of diabetes from insulin injections. Two to 14 months after being transplanted in a simple procedure resembling a transfusion at the University of Alberta in Edmonton, the cells are still working in all eight patients, half of whom were treated almost a year ago.

headline.main: Cell Transplants Offer Hope For Severe Cases of Diabetes

docs.abstract: Researchers in Canada, in important advance, report that transplants of insulin-producing cells have freed eight patients with a severe form of diabetes from insulin injections; report that two to 14 months after being transplanted in simple procedure resembling transfusion at University of Alberta in Edmonton, cells are still working in all eight patients, half of whom were treated almost year ago; patients, who had type 1 diabetes, in which body produces little or no insulin, no longer have any symptoms of the disease; although they no longer need insulin to control their blood sugar, they now must take other drugs to prevent rejection of transplants; drawing (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Those of us who lived through the headiest days of the 60's counterculture, when pie-in-the-sky hippie gurus were popping up like daisies in July, should feel more than a twinge of deja vu watching Jon Reiss's impassioned documentary film ''Better Living Through Circuitry.'' An enthusiastic exploration of today's rave culture and the beat-driven electronic music that fuels it, the movie is packed with upbeat pronouncements by flush-faced techno-wizards and partygoers extolling the transformational power of these all-night dance parties. Usually held in nontraditional party spaces (abandoned warehouses and outdoor desert settings are favorite sites), these events, programmed by visionary disc jockeys and lighting designers, synergize electronic music, psychedelic decor and drugs (usually Ecstasy) to send partygoers into a communal ecstatic state. Some rave parties are attended by thousands who may drive hundreds of miles to surrender to the beat.

headline.main: The Synergy! The Ecstasy! The Biology!

docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews documentary film Better Living Through Circuitry, directed by Jon Reiss; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Responding to widely publicized lapses in medical experiments, the Clinton administration announced today that it would seek authority from Congress to levy fines of up to $250,000 on scientists who violate federal rules for human research and $1 million on the universities that employ them. The proposed fines are part of a broad plan, unveiled this morning by Donna E. Shalala, the secretary of health and human services, to better protect the thousands of patients who each year volunteer for medical experiments, including tests of new drugs and cutting-edge treatments like gene therapy. It comes two days before officials are to testify at a Senate hearing on patient safety.

headline.main: Fines Proposed for Violations of Human Research Rules

docs.abstract: Health Sec Donna E Shalala, responding to lapses in medical experiments, says Clinton administration will ask Congress for authority to fine scientists and universities that employ them who violate federal rules for human research; fines are part of broad plan, set to take effect immediately, to better protect volunteers in medical experiments; Pres Clinton calls plan 'critical first step' toward improving patient safety; plan requires bioethics training for clinical researchers and sets conflict-of-interest guidelines for doctors with financial stakes in their studies (M)
docs.snippet: Responding to widely publicized lapses in medical experiments, the Clinton administration announced today that it would seek authority from Congress to levy fines of up to $250,000 on scientists who violate federal rules for human research and $1...

docs.lead_paragraph: With high-carbohydrate foods getting such a bad rap, it is refreshing to hear about new findings that clearly demonstrate the health value of a carbohydrate-rich diet, as long as it contains the right carbohydrates, replete with soluble and insoluble fiber, the way nature made them. Fiber has also been knocked around a bit lately, after three disappointing studies failed to find that a high-fiber diet helped to prevent colon cancer. If preventing colon cancer was the only reason to eat fiber, I would say you could safely abandon bran muffins, whole-grain cereals, beans and peas and fiber-rich fruits and vegetables and return to a pristine diet of pasty white bread. But dietary fiber, as the new study so graphically showed, has myriad health benefits. The study also shows that people need not resort to a very low-fat diet to reap those benefits, as long as the fat in their diets is also the right kind.

headline.main: Vindication for the Maligned Fiber Diet

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on the health value of a carbohydrate-rich diet replete with soluble and insoluble fiber, especially for diabetics (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of doctors across the country have been boycotting drug products made by Merck & Company, one of the world's largest drug manufacturers, in a bitter fight over the collective bargaining rights of doctors, pharmacists and other health care professionals. Leaders of the Federation of Physicians and Dentists, a labor union, called the boycott several weeks ago -- to punish Merck, they said, for its position on legislation pending in Congress.

headline.main: Doctors in Antitrust Fight Boycott Merck Products

docs.abstract: Hundreds of doctors nationwide are boycotting drug products made by Merck & Company, one of world's largest drug manufacturers, in bitter fight over collective bargaining rights of doctors, pharmacists and other health care professionals; leaders of Federation of Physicians and Dentists, labor union, is punishing company for its position opposing legislation pending in Congress that would grant antitrust waiver to physicians and other health care professionals making it easier for them to band together to negotiate with health insurance plans and managed care companies; company has stake in legislation since its has subsidiary that manages drug benefits for 52 million people (M)
